text: myself and many others have been in
discussion with the Israeli government
about making sure the building materials
get into Gaza I don't think in the end
that's going to be the problem actually
I think that there there is a an
agreement being worked out which I'm
reasonably confident about that will
allow construction material to go into
Gaza and rebuild the infrastructure but
also for private housing there's a whole
set of other measures we want to take in
order to help garzo help its private
sector for example but I think the real
question is you can reconstruct Gaza but
are we going to have a lasting peace and
make sure we don't go back into the
cycle of destruction again and that I
think will also require a political
framework a political horizon and a
Palestinian politics that's unified on
the basis of of peace so I think it's
these bigger political questions that
are really the issue it was interesting
I thought today at the Egyptian
president Fattah al-sisi he called for
the vision of the Arab Peace Initiative
to be considered that just for a viewer
that would be full recognition of the
Jewish state but only if it gives up all
land seized in the 1967 Middle East war
and agrees to and I quote open to
interpretation a just solution for
Palestinian refugees what did you think
of that statement by President al-sisi I
mean I think the part of Arab Peace
Initiative remains one of the most
important things that's happened in the
Middle East over the last couple of
decades it does provide a basis for
going forward you know 67 borders with
agreed land swaps is essentially the you
know that's them as a where the
traditional formula for the borders of a
Palestinian state but I think my point
really is that you know you can probably
take 90% of that conference today from
the international community from the
Arab world and so on and they would have
rough agreement on the parameters of a
of a of a of a deal to create a
Palestinian state the the issue in the
challenge is the politics both Israeli
and Palestinian that at the moment
aren't hearing in a way that allow us to
to take that that pretty clear
International vision and make it a
reality so that's why I say I think the
critical thing is really the politics so
how do you then get in there and begin
to try and battle the ideological
political positions that are obviously
so firmly entrenched right I think the
first thing is if we're gonna
reconstruct Gaza it should be done under
the authority of the Palestinian
Authority and President Abbas and Prime
Minister Prime Minister Mandela and it's
very important that that process of
change in Gaza is led by unified
politics in other words Gaza and West
Bank together so Hamas and Fatah which
are the two Palestinian main Palestinian
parties have agreed that they will have
a process of reconciliation
we need that happen but we needed to
happen on a basis of peace which also
takes account of Israel's security and
the second thing is that we need an
Israeli politics we need to have a clear
way forward so that when the
Palestinians get into a negotiation they
know there's a serious political horizon
for statehood because otherwise they
think we're just going to go and talk
and talk and not come to an agreement so
it's it's as I say it's the political
challenge that I think is an even bigger
challenge than putting the bricks and
mortar back into Gaza which probably
probably can be done
